messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
> since we were young, but in QS!
>
> > I took Paul's original message to be a suggestion for standardized
> > spelling, though it appears I may have misjudged that.
>
> Indeed, it is a call for radically unstandardized spelling: you can
> decipher it, but reading it is going to be a real problem.
>

No its not. I actually agree with you that having a standardized
spelling would make reading much easier. In fact, it may be essential
to have standradized, or fairly standardized spelling.

If you read my posts, I have stated several times that QS either must
have standardized spelling or be able to be mapped to the IPA. If it
has niether, then how are we to understand what is written? For
example, I understand #26 to be pronounced like /i/, and I spell
"seat" Sis-If-Tut. You of course read the word as "sit." That is why I
insisted on an accurate description of the letters (especially the
vowels) in IPA. And if you think that I am just making up a
hypothecial situation, thinking that no one could ever confuse /i/
with /I/ from the manual, I am looking at page 2 right now, which
gives an example of #22 as in the word "busy," underlining both the
"u" in the word and the "y." But the final "y" has a /i/ sound, not /I/!

But yes, I tend to prefer a QS that is more or less standradized. When
I suggested this a few weeks ago, I met with great resistance. We do
read by word recognition. In fact, I read a book on writing systems a
few years ago that suggested that TO was actually a pretty good system
for writing English precisely because of its extra letters, which
makes site reading easier. I've often wondered how right the author
is. For example, as a beginner, I have a hard time differentiating
between #28, #30, #34, and #36. I have to stop each time and figure
out them out. While these letters may be easy to write, I wonder if
they make QS impractical for publishing books (if it should ever get
to that stage!)--or will more practice prove that these letters are
not a problem?
